Hi all,,,,,,,,,,,for Ron H. and Bob R,,,,,,,,,,,I bought a Goto tanto tsuba with the finest [smallest] nanako granules I've ever seen,,,,,,,,,,and the definition [or resolution] between the granules was very 'smeared',,,,,,,,,,but after inspection under a 10X glass, I saw that a grime of 400 to 500 years was my problem,,,,,,,,,,,,,I did a light scrubbing using diluted dish detergent and a very soft tooth brush and the definition of the nanako granules came back like magic,,,,,,,,,,,,after washing with water and carefully drying with soft cotton cloth, I coated with choji oil,,,,,,,,,,results of this cleaning were quite acceptable.
Regards, Bruce Michener.

From: Bob Rossman

Ron,

I had this same problem on a Kozuka. Seems that with
age gunk gets in all the textures of them. I'm not
sure that I won't get flamed for this but I found that
a wooden toothpick to pick out the big stuff and then
a very soft-headed toothbrush and some water helps to
break up and get rid of the rest of it. I'm not sure
if this is a good or sanctioned way to do it but it
worked for me.

Bob R

--- Ron Hartmann <swords@...> wrote:

Looking closer, I suspect the nanako has
> become smooth in places not from wear, but from
